awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research: Amazonian Governance to Enable a Transition to Sustainability (AGENTS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Global environmental change, environmental degradation and resource pressures have created unprecedented situations for societies worldwide.  The slow progress on addressing these challenges has led to increasing emphasis on the need to go beyond the study and encouragement of incremental change. Conventional knowledge and capacity building to tackle the challenges associated with sustainability have had limited positive impacts; consequently, there is growing need for more fundamental knowledge on how transformations in the way societies interact both with each other and with the natural environment.  Societal transformations refer to profound and enduring systemic changes that typically involve social, cultural, technological, political, economic and environmental processes. A comprehensive and concerted research initiative is needed that can boost research on transformations to sustainability and catalyze new kinds of solutions to environmental and social challenges. 

This award supports U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 19-country initiative through the Belmont Forum- NORFACE-ISSC.  Transformations to Sustainability (T2S) is a multilateral initiative designed to support research projects that will contribute to re-structuring the broad field of sustainability research.  Co-production of knowledge and research problem formulation is considered to be critical to the process of societal transformation and each project engages stakeholders or community-based partners.  The initiative seeks to develop the fundamental knowledge societies require to help develop transformations to sustainability which are of significant social concern throughout the world and of great relevance to both academics and stakeholders.  The T2S program aims to build capacity, overcome fragmentation and have a lasting impact on both society and the research landscape by cultivating durable research collaboration across multiple borders, disciplinary boundaries, and with practitioners and societal partners. This includes facilitating the development of new research collaborations with parts of the world which are not often involved in large-scale international research efforts, notably low- and middle-income countries.  The funds provided in this award will be used to support U.S. participants to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., civil society, NGOs, and industry).  Participants from other countries are funded through their national funding organizations. 

This project seeks to assess land use practices that reconcile forest conservation and food production, and how these practices are connected across scales through sustainable landscape governance.  The Amazon basin is a global keystone region: locally, continentally and globally it hosts a wide array of environmental services, socio-cultural diversity, and economic activities.  Governing these multiple dimensions amid pressing social-environmental, and global environmental change is one of the most pressing challenges for sustainability.  The project will contribute approaches and analytical tools to conceptualize, assess, map, and quantify various land use practices, management, and conservation of forests and ecosystems in several locations across Brazil, Peru, and Bolivia representing diverse social-ecological systems and sustainability challenges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Belmont Forum Project: Amazonian Governance to Enable a Transition to Sustainability (AGENTS)

The AGENTS project is composed of a research consortium, supported under the auspices of the Belmont Forum and NORFACE collaborative funding program, gathering senior researchers from six institutions: Indiana University – Bloomington (USA), the University of Campinas, the University of Amsterdam (The Nederland), Stockholm University (Sweden), the Swedish University for Agricultural Sciences (Sweden), and the University of Colorado (USA).

The participating researchers and students have worked to develop new analytical approaches and tools to catalyze recognition of and actual contributions of existing, but often scattered "pieces of solutions" [initiatives] to protect and govern biodiversity and landscapes in the Amazon. Place-based in nature, these initiatives focus on issues of improving land and resource conservation and governance, income and employment, the sustainability of production systems and value-aggregation of local products, promote associativism and cooperativism, gender inclusion, food security and health, among others. The project has successfully engaged multiple stakeholder in the participatory research, developed a geospatial platform and conducted multi-temporal analysis of land change at multiple units of analysis, and  developed a novel database of place-based sustainability initiatives, which includes over 200 initiatives in Brazil and Peru (167 in great detail), located in more than 900 localities around the region [see figure]. We have systematically measured/compiled over a 120 variables describing these initiatives (biophysical, socioeconomic and institutional characteristics).

One important outcome of the project is to facilitate connections between place-based initiatives throughout the Amazon basin. Despite the ongoing pandemic, the project has regularly convened governance actors at the local and regional levels to webinars and virtual dialogue workshops. Through these regular events, local actors have enriched their social networks and have initiated new experiments for improving local governance outcomes. The project is organizing a final workshop and public seminar in the Brazilian Amazon (August 2022) to bring together leaders of place-based initiatives to showcase their work and to discuss opportunities and challenges moving forward. Another project output is the production of a short-video series “Agents of Transformation” showcasing about 20 initiatives documented by the project.

Apart from publishing high-profile papers in journals such as PNAS, World Development, Land Use Policy, and Current Opinion in Environmental Sustainability, the project has contributed to the growth and expansion of our Peruvian partner organization, Centro Bartolome de las Casas, to begin working with forest communities in the Peruvian Amazon (they previously only worked in the valleys and highlands areas of Peru). Also relevant, the project offered training opportunities for two post-doctoral researchers, 7 graduate students, and 2 undergraduates. Three master thesis (University of Amsterdam) and 1 doctoral dissertation have been completed (University of Colorado) with two other doctoral dissertations underway (Indiana University, University of Amsterdam).

The numerous products available in the project’s website (including reports, virtual workshops, webinars, and publicly available publications) have also contributed to making local place-based initiatives more visible to a variety of governance actors, including members of local grassroots organizations, local and regional government officials, members of civil society, and the academic research communities.  Finally, our project is producing outputs intended to impact teaching methods. For instance, the project is documenting and compiling a series of case studies on innovative forest governance from study sites, which will form a part of a special issue in the journal ELEMENTA. The purpose of the special issue is to promote the use of case studies in the teaching of environmental policy analysis.
